Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Ronald Reagan lost Wisconsin in his second election, while the claim states that Wisconsin was the only state he lost.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the statement that no Republican presidential candidate had won Wisconsin since Dwight Eisenhower in 1952.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores alternative explanations by not acknowledging the victories of Richard Nixon in Wisconsin in 1960, 1968, and 1972, and Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of Trump's victory in Wisconsin by stating that it was the first time since Dwight Eisenhower in 1952 that a Republican presidential candidate won the state, disregarding the victories of Nixon and Reagan.
Falters at times: The claim falters by incorrectly stating that Wisconsin was the only state Ronald Reagan lost in his second election, when in fact he lost Minnesota as well.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that no Republican presidential candidate had won Wisconsin since Dwight Eisenhower in 1952, without considering the victories of Nixon and Reagan.
Understate: The claim understates the number of Republican presidential candidates who won Wisconsin after Dwight Eisenhower by only mentioning Ronald Reagan's victories and omitting Nixon's victories.
